componenttext: And our next question today comes from Doug Leggate of Bank of America Merrill Lynch.

headline: Cabot Oil & Gas Corporation, Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2017
componenttextpreview: This is John -- no, this is not Doug. This is John Abbott calling in on behalf of Doug. Just a couple of quick questions on our side. First, how are you thinking about the ramp, your ramp into Atlantic Sunrise? Are you thinking about growing aggressively
componenttext:
This is John -- no, this is not Doug. This is John Abbott calling in on behalf of Doug. Just a couple of quick questions on our side. First, how are you thinking about the ramp, your ramp into Atlantic Sunrise? Are you thinking about growing aggressively into that or taking volumes potentially from -- that are constrained elsewhere and moving it over? 
And then second, what -- and second, with regards to the Pennsylvania permit, what is the -- what benchmark should we be looking there in order to see that get finished? I mean, you're expecting it here shortly, but what else needs to be done?

headline: Cabot Oil & Gas Corporation, Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2017
componenttextpreview: Okay, I'll return -- I'll give the second part of that to Jeff. But on the Atlantic Sunrise growth, we've kind of been clear on the ramp. It's not going to be instantaneously incremental. We are going to shift volumes out of basin where we've had punitive
componenttext: Okay, I'll return -- I'll give the second part of that to Jeff. But on the Atlantic Sunrise growth, we've kind of been clear on the ramp. It's not going to be instantaneously incremental. We are going to shift volumes out of basin where we've had punitive differentials. We think with that shift that we should see, as we expect, a narrowing of that differential in basin, which would affect positively the gas that we do continue to produce in basin. And then we will continue to grow the volumes incrementally into the new capacity that Sunrise affords us. So it'll be -- it won't be instantaneous. But we certainly are planning our '18 program as we're preparing to present to our board in October an increased capital program for '18 that would allow us to grow our production in the 15% to 25% range, as we have outlined.

headline: Cabot Oil & Gas Corporation, Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2017
componenttextpreview: Appreciate that. And then with regards to the Pennsylvania permit, what do you see -- what's left there for that to be done?
componenttext: Appreciate that. And then with regards to the Pennsylvania permit, what do you see -- what's left there for that to be done?

headline: Cabot Oil & Gas Corporation, Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2017
componenttextpreview: Yes, okay, John. Yes, we have 2 outstanding permits. They're commonly known as the Section 102 and Section 105 permits. You're probably aware that the Pennsylvania DEP went out for public comments back in May on these 2 permits, but that was closed late J
componenttext: Yes, okay, John. Yes, we have 2 outstanding permits. They're commonly known as the Section 102 and Section 105 permits. You're probably aware that the Pennsylvania DEP went out for public comments back in May on these 2 permits, but that was closed late June. There were several thousand comments submitted. And quite frankly, a lot of them were positive. And right now, the DEP is sorting through those comments, preparing answers and finalizing the last-minute data request from questions that may have come up during that comment period. So we're expecting, going forward, that these permits are just getting the final touches put to them, so to speak. And they'll be out the door here mid- to late August.

headline: Cabot Oil & Gas Corporation, Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2017
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from Brian Singer, Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: And our next question comes from Brian Singer, Goldman Sachs.

headline: Cabot Oil & Gas Corporation, Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2017
componenttextpreview: Dan, in the past, you've indicated interest in maintaining some level of diversification in the portfolio, even if modest, with the Eagle Ford representing that place in the portfolio today. With the focus, understandably, on returning cash to shareholder
componenttext: Dan, in the past, you've indicated interest in maintaining some level of diversification in the portfolio, even if modest, with the Eagle Ford representing that place in the portfolio today. With the focus, understandably, on returning cash to shareholders even ahead of Eagle Ford drilling, are you now more comfortable with the asset base being even more leveraged to Northeast PA? And if so, are there changes that are increasing your long-term confidence in growth from the region beyond a couple of pipelines and power plants that you've spoken about today?

headline: Cabot Oil & Gas Corporation, Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2017
componenttextpreview: Well, as we get closer to the realization that we will be able to start construction on infrastructure and move significant volumes, not only in the pipelines up there, but I think there's other projects that would be supportive of the differentials and r
componenttext:
Well, as we get closer to the realization that we will be able to start construction on infrastructure and move significant volumes, not only in the pipelines up there, but I think there's other projects that would be supportive of the differentials and realizations that -- and improve the realizations that we've seen in the past. As we go through that process and we get shovels in the ground, absolutely, we're incrementally more comfortable about, not only our growth horizon, but also our ability to return even more free cash to our coffer by virtue of the growth and improved differentials. There's still a look at a -- the 2 exploration programs that we feel like, if successful, could return significant value for our shareholders. And we are going vet those through the data-gathering process that I've outlined. With the -- going out and looking out in the Northeast and looking at the power plant projects, looking at the Atlantic Sunrise, yes, we have anticipation of Constitution also securing the approval later, whether it's 2019 or 2020. We think that can be an incremental gain. We do know that there is committed-to-firm capacity in the infrastructure up there that might not be filled by those holders of that firm that also provides an avenue for future growth up there also. 
So between now and 2020, compared to where Cabot has been on the last 3 years, just trying to battle the regulators and the anti-group trying to stop pipeline from being installed, I am extremely optimistic about the near term for Cabot. And our concern about diversity or growth mitigates each day as we get closer to these infrastructure approvals.

headline: Cabot Oil & Gas Corporation, Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2017
componenttextpreview: Great, and that's helpful. Small follow-up on exploration. And I think in your comments you mentioned that one of the 2 projects was in Texas. Can you just -- I think last quarter, you said that at least one of the projects was seeking oil. Is that still
componenttext: Great, and that's helpful. Small follow-up on exploration. And I think in your comments you mentioned that one of the 2 projects was in Texas. Can you just -- I think last quarter, you said that at least one of the projects was seeking oil. Is that still the case? Can you give any color on the second project? And when, on either one, there'll be more color that you can share from a well-performance perspective?

headline: Cabot Oil & Gas Corporation, Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2017
componenttextpreview: Yes, we are. With these 2 prospects, they are tied to a diversity, if you will, in the commodity mix. So yes, oil is the focus. And as we gather additional information through between now and the end of the year, we would only be speculating in the, what
componenttext:
Yes, we are. With these 2 prospects, they are tied to a diversity, if you will, in the commodity mix. So yes, oil is the focus. And as we gather additional information through between now and the end of the year, we would only be speculating in the, what we anticipate we do, continue to do our due diligence and looking at the data that we have in hand, looking at the reprocess seismic that we continue to work and continue to gather more data, and some of it being subsurface data from the past in each of these prospect areas. So the data we gather continues to reinforce our concepts on both of these prospects. 
So from timing, Brian, on when we might have something solid, I really think it would be after the first of the year. Ideally, what I would love to see would be 4 or so wells in each prospect area tested, some flow back period. And with those test and flow back period, we can give you cost examples. We could give you return profiles. We could even look at the quality of fluid mix to talk a little bit more in-depth about what it's going to take on the surface side of the business and infrastructure side and give assurances that we've mitigated risk on program execution from logistics. That's when I would feel great about talking about it. I'm sure we'll be asked about it, and maybe we'll process out a little bit of information along the way. But that's kind of, overall, in a summary fashion, how I look at releasing data on exploratory projects.

componenttext: Sure, Jeffrey. So we, as a shipper on that project, we do communicate quite a bit with the operator and the other partners. The New Jersey denial was not unexpected. They realized that there's additional data that was necessary and required. And quite frankly, they were moving toward that. And when we lost the FERC quorum, as you know, PennEast is still pending a certificate. But in this law, I guess, the -- what I understand is they've moved toward the complete application at this point, and it will get a second look.

componenttext: Okay, great. And then just on -- I just want to make sure I wasn't confused. Did you say that you're going to drill 5 total exploratory wells second half? Or is it going to be 5 in each one of these 2 exploratory areas that you've referred to?

headline: Cabot Oil & Gas Corporation, Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2017
componenttextpreview: Yes. Two different things. One, we're going to plan within our $125 million budget to drill 5 exploratory wells in the second half. My comment on having 5 wells in each prospect was just an example that says that ideally, I would like to have, before we m
componenttext: Yes. Two different things. One, we're going to plan within our $125 million budget to drill 5 exploratory wells in the second half. My comment on having 5 wells in each prospect was just an example that says that ideally, I would like to have, before we make full disclosure or full release, I would like to have that level of detail to be able to lay out and give the shareholder the confidence that we have really vetted these projects, as opposed to coming out with just a little bit of information that would be maybe somewhat more speculative or not having any type of term to a test, except for --  in 1 area or 2 areas or something like that. I'd like to be able to see a little bit more information before we would make any release. I understand entirely though, as we get pushed to release information, that we'll do our best to accommodate those request without giving away too much information and without speculating too much.

componenttext: Okay. And with that color that you just provided, I'm just wondering, the 5 wells you're going to drill, are you going to do some preliminary exploration in both of the plays? Or are you concentrating the 5 wells in 1 of them at this time?

headline: Cabot Oil & Gas Corporation, Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2017
componenttextpreview: No. We are, right now, have -- we have 4 wells in 1 area. And the 4 wells that we have in the one area is the area that we had less subsurface control points to be able to mature our concept. And so we are gathering additional data there. One well in the
componenttext: No. We are, right now, have -- we have 4 wells in 1 area. And the 4 wells that we have in the one area is the area that we had less subsurface control points to be able to mature our concept. And so we are gathering additional data there. One well in the other area -- in this other area, we had and have more subsurface information. And we have more information to mature our concept upfront in that area. But the drilling of the well would assist us in proof-of-concept on some of our ideas.

headline: Cabot Oil & Gas Corporation, Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2017
componenttextpreview: Maybe first one for Scott, just on uses of capital. Just how are you thinking about sort of balancing the buyback versus the '18 maturity?
componenttext: Maybe first one for Scott, just on uses of capital. Just how are you thinking about sort of balancing the buyback versus the '18 maturity?

headline: Cabot Oil & Gas Corporation, Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2017
componenttextpreview: I think it's not a -- it's definitely not with our financial position in either/or. As you know, we have a fully undrawn revolver and -- of $1.7 billion. So in worst case scenario, if we saw an opportunity to use disproportionate share of that free cash p
componenttext:
I think it's not a -- it's definitely not with our financial position in either/or. As you know, we have a fully undrawn revolver and -- of $1.7 billion. So in worst case scenario, if we saw an opportunity to use disproportionate share of that free cash plus what's on our balance sheet, being opportunistic, buying in shares, we would follow through on that opportunity and not worry about that we need to hold some of that reserve for the '18 maturity. The '18 maturity does go current. So you'll see it as current. Actually, this month, most of it does. So you'll see it in current in the third quarter 10-Q. 
As many of you know, Cabot is unrated by design over the years. One of the things we're going to explore is a refinancing strategy on that, where we actually go to the public markets, get some indications from the agencies. We haven't been hurt by not being rated. At the same time, the size of the company we are and where we're at in our kind of life cycle, it's probably time to explore that option. So that will also be taking place over the next, probably, 6 to 8 to 10 months.

headline: Cabot Oil & Gas Corporation, Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2017
componenttextpreview: Okay. So help me with that. If you're not considered investment grade, don't you have to post LCs for the pipes?
componenttext: Okay. So help me with that. If you're not considered investment grade, don't you have to post LCs for the pipes?

componenttext: No, because we have a long-standing track record. And we are investment grade in the private placement market. And we've worked through all those hurdles over the years.

headline: Cabot Oil & Gas Corporation, Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2017
componenttextpreview: Okay, great. And then maybe one just for Jeff on Constitution, given what we've seen with Millennium and Northern Access here as of late. I mean, any insights into the appeal? Or maybe how you're thinking about the future paths to take going forward?
componenttext: Okay, great. And then maybe one just for Jeff on Constitution, given what we've seen with Millennium and Northern Access here as of late. I mean, any insights into the appeal? Or maybe how you're thinking about the future paths to take going forward?

headline: Cabot Oil & Gas Corporation, Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2017
componenttextpreview: Sure, Holly. Of course, not just with Millennium and also with National Fuel. I hesitate to use the word, plot thickens. It may be appropriate. And regarding the Constitution and our appeal, we're kind of on the tail-end of the path period, where we expec
componenttext:
Sure, Holly. Of course, not just with Millennium and also with National Fuel. I hesitate to use the word, plot thickens. It may be appropriate. And regarding the Constitution and our appeal, we're kind of on the tail-end of the path period, where we expected the Second Circuit to give us a ruling. So that's getting close. It is a complicated case, so it may not be right around the corner. But our expectations are that we'll see something out of the courts fairly soon. I think that the bottom line on the Millennium case was the impending back authority levels to the FERC is obviously a very good thing, and we'll see how that plays out. Probably has a shorter duration to play out as we -- in the next few months as we see what the DEC actually does with that permit application here soon. 
And then National Fuel, of course, has such a similar set of facts that we have with Constitution in their plate with the short pipeline and can be a New York-based company and the job creations and all the good things that, that new pipeline does is, again, very similar to Constitution. And we expect some clarity on just how we're going to be operating in New York.

headline: Cabot Oil & Gas Corporation, Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2017

componenttext: And our next question comes from Drew Venker of Morgan Stanley.

headline: Cabot Oil & Gas Corporation, Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2017
componenttextpreview: I was hoping you could speak to how this exploration program might play into your decisions around plans to accelerate return of cash to shareholders, and how you kind of envision the timing. Because obviously, results are difficult to predict, as you had
componenttext: I was hoping you could speak to how this exploration program might play into your decisions around plans to accelerate return of cash to shareholders, and how you kind of envision the timing. Because obviously, results are difficult to predict, as you had noted. And you might want to engage in a lot more testing before making a call to go to development mode, or you might be disappointed and decide to cool down the program. So maybe you can just speak to that.

headline: Cabot Oil & Gas Corporation, Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2017
componenttextpreview: Yes, that's -- it could be a -- I can make a short answer a long answer. I'll try to get it in between. But our idea is to always improve our lie and to improve our capital efficiency. We believe that the best areas to allocate capital are in core areas,
componenttext:
Yes, that's -- it could be a -- I can make a short answer a long answer. I'll try to get it in between. But our idea is to always improve our lie and to improve our capital efficiency. We believe that the best areas to allocate capital are in core areas, and I would define core areas are -- as like our Marcellus. And there are probably are several others may be very core areas in the oil areas that would allow capital to be allocated, returns that would generate, not only growth, but also free cash. Our objective is to try to improve our lie over any areas, like our Eagle Ford, that I do not -- it's a good asset, certainly we're running, even at these lower-threshold commodity prices, our weighted average cost of capital. But I don't believe the company survives on just drilling areas that have a return profile based on the weighted cost of capital. So our objective would be to improve our lie and be able to do it in a way that would return, not only significant returns-focused growth, but also free cash, which would in fact allow us to generate more free cash to give back to shareholders. 
So that's our objective. If we were on your fail case or uncertain case, if we were to not be able to get to a core asset profile with our exploration program, and then, though we saw that our infrastructure projects we're taking off of the Marcellus, we decided to go in that direction solely as an ongoing project, which by the way, is a high-class problem to have with those assets, if we made that decision, I am confident with the subsurface data we have, with the concept design we've created, that there is going to be incremental value in these assets, in these 2 projects. And if, in fact, they were not core-type projects for us, I'd still think that with the dollars invested, entry level at a very, very low cost, that we would be able to generate significant returns for the shareholder if, in fact, we decided to monetize those assets.

headline: Cabot Oil & Gas Corporation, Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2017

componenttext: Okay, and that's all very helpful color, Dan. And just on the timing of when you think you would be able to make a call or would like to make a call, is that in the next 12 months? Or is it end of '18 or potentially beyond that before you decide, it really does look like a core play or it doesn't?

componenttext: Yes, yes, Drew. I would think that -- I would be surprised if it goes beyond 12 months that we would not be able to rationalize where, with a fairly high degree of confidence, where in our return profile expectations that these 2 projects would fall.

headline: Cabot Oil & Gas Corporation, Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2017
componenttextpreview: Could you elaborate a little bit more on the pilot program that you have in the Eagle Ford to reduce well costs? Is that a function that you've tried some enhanced completions there, and you're looking at some tweaks on just optimizing that cost down, and
componenttext: Could you elaborate a little bit more on the pilot program that you have in the Eagle Ford to reduce well costs? Is that a function that you've tried some enhanced completions there, and you're looking at some tweaks on just optimizing that cost down, and perhaps you maybe use a bit too much services on these wells? Or is it a -- how are you guys thinking about balancing that? And what's the pilot program really looking at?

headline: Cabot Oil & Gas Corporation, Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2017
componenttextpreview: Yes, yes, good question, David. I'll let Steven Lindeman fill that question.
componenttext: Yes, yes, good question, David. I'll let Steven Lindeman fill that question.

headline: Cabot Oil & Gas Corporation, Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2017
componenttextpreview: David, throughout the year, we've done a number of things. Again, as we released, we've been working to drive our drilling cost by drilling longer laterals. In this quarter, we completed lateral lengths up to 12,000 feet. And in addition to longer lateral
componenttext: David, throughout the year, we've done a number of things. Again, as we released, we've been working to drive our drilling cost by drilling longer laterals. In this quarter, we completed lateral lengths up to 12,000 feet. And in addition to longer laterals, we've been doing some cluster spacing testing, some diverter testing, and those are the kind of results that we're digesting right now. We've also upped our sand volume, which is one of the things of late that have increased completion costs. And so as we get more production data in on this population of wells, we're going to look at what combination, or what -- how we can optimize that to increase the return, whether we decrease sand, whether we adjust our clusters or look at what lateral lengths we might go to. So those are all  the knobs that we're working out right now.

headline: Cabot Oil & Gas Corporation, Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2017
componenttextpreview: Okay. And is that just a function of the longer clean-up times? This might cannibalize some of the returns there, just with the larger sand volumes.
componenttext: Okay. And is that just a function of the longer clean-up times? This might cannibalize some of the returns there, just with the larger sand volumes.

headline: Cabot Oil & Gas Corporation, Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2017
componenttextpreview: Yes. The -- clearly, what we're trying to do from a return perspective is up the initial rate. But obviously, our long-term goal is to increase reserves from each well. And we're happy with what we're seeing in terms of the reserve profile that we're seei
componenttext: Yes. The -- clearly, what we're trying to do from a return perspective is up the initial rate. But obviously, our long-term goal is to increase reserves from each well. And we're happy with what we're seeing in terms of the reserve profile that we're seeing a flatter decline. But we just -- with the additional water that's being applied, and maybe it's a function of the additional cluster, so that water is staying nearer to the wellbore. It's just taking us longer to update those decrease.

headline: Cabot Oil & Gas Corporation, Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2017
componenttextpreview: That's helpful color. And the last one for me, Dan, this -- I think recently, you kind of discussed the sensitivity around the Eagle Ford program. It sounds like the back half of the year, you said that capital is locked in for a leasehold. As you get int
componenttext: That's helpful color. And the last one for me, Dan, this -- I think recently, you kind of discussed the sensitivity around the Eagle Ford program. It sounds like the back half of the year, you said that capital is locked in for a leasehold. As you get into '18, is the Eagle Ford program -- are you at a decision point, really, that's sensitive to commodity price as to whether you want to sell this asset or sort of continue in a single rig sort of development mode? And is that price point closer to $50? Or...

headline: Cabot Oil & Gas Corporation, Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2017
componenttextpreview: Yes, at the level that we're in right now for oil commodity prices, what we've been doing with the capital allocation and the decision point to allocate capital to the Eagle Ford has been really based on lease obligations and maintaining our commitment an
componenttext:
Yes, at the level that we're in right now for oil commodity prices, what we've been doing with the capital allocation and the decision point to allocate capital to the Eagle Ford has been really based on lease obligations and maintaining our commitment and not losing any of the optionality that we would have in the future. And certainly, in the event that we do get improvements in the commodity price, that either way, whether we decide to allocate additional capital to it or if we decide to monetize, in either case, we want to maintain and keep all of our optionality and -- in it. And so the pinch point is, what kind of lease requirements that we need to complete, to maintain that full leasehold position. 
So when you look at our entire program, we have -- we're running dual tracks here. We're looking at our return profile with every dollar we spend, and I understand the angst with shareholders on, why are you allocating money to a project that is not returning the superior returns, that maybe a Marcellus would. But again, there's a lot of capital in the industry being allocated that don't return what the Marcellus does. And I think, though, that when we move forward with our exploratory projects, we do increase our optionality with infrastructure build-out. It gives us the ability to be a little bit more aggressive, if you will, in the decisions we make on where you want to allocate, how we want to allocate, what we want to monetize, and do we have some other options to maybe create additional new venture projects that need a threshold definition, as we would say, as a core asset for us. 
So we're really running some dual tracks right now with -- and still trying to maintain our acreage position in the Eagle Ford. And the team has done a great job. That has allowed us to, again, continue to get the returns we want. But everybody is wanting to have a program that would generate greater returns from the cost of capital.

headline: Cabot Oil & Gas Corporation, Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2017

componenttext: I was hoping to just probe a little bit more into this -- the, really, the hurdle rate or threshold rate you're going to judge these new venture plays against. And if you can give us kind of a ballpark project return that really will improve your lie, or generate growth and free cash flow. I know you've laid out the Eagle Ford is 45% project return at $50 and Marcellus Shale is 120% at $2. I would imagine it is somewhere in between there. What's kind of your ballpark rule of thumb? Or what's acceptable to you?

headline: Cabot Oil & Gas Corporation, Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2017
componenttextpreview: Yes. Mike, I'm not going to get down that granular. We have described exactly what you just laid out, that we're looking to improve our lie. We're looking to be able to find projects that would enhance the shareholders' value. And we think that from an Ea
componenttext: Yes. Mike, I'm not going to get down that granular. We have described exactly what you just laid out, that we're looking to improve our lie. We're looking to be able to find projects that would enhance the shareholders' value. And we think that from an Eagle Ford position-type asset, I don't consider that level of return as core. I do return -- I do define our Marcellus that  you've laid out as core. And we're just trying to, again, improve our efficiency, and we look at a project that will allow us to do what I've said in the past. And that's be able to grow the asset and generate free cash. So you're going to be in a good return zip code if you're able to accomplish that.

headline: Cabot Oil & Gas Corporation, Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2017
componenttextpreview: Okay, great. Fair enough. And just a follow-up for me. Just wondering if I'm making the right read here, read between the lines, that the share repurchase is really kind of a sign that your confidence in receiving the final permit -- permits that Atlantic
componenttext: Okay, great. Fair enough. And just a follow-up for me. Just wondering if I'm making the right read here, read between the lines, that the share repurchase is really kind of a sign that your confidence in receiving the final permit -- permits that Atlantic Sunrise has really only increased over the last quarter and remains pretty high.

headline: Cabot Oil & Gas Corporation, Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2017
componenttextpreview: Well, it's 2 things: One, that we had the available cash. We had -- as you came out of the third quarter of '16, fourth quarter of '16, and then the first quarter of '17, we saw how significantly the differentials narrowed. And we saw, under a more normal
componenttext:
Well, it's 2 things: One, that we had the available cash. We had -- as you came out of the third quarter of '16, fourth quarter of '16, and then the first quarter of '17, we saw how significantly the differentials narrowed. And we saw, under a more normal condition, what our project would generate in free cash with realizations in the range that we realized for the first half of this year. 
So a combination of, again, seeing good realizations that we hadn't seen in maybe 3 years come to fruition, but also, to your point, getting closer to the approval process and narrowing down on the commissioning of these infrastructures. Both of those gave us the confidence to not only increase our dividend by 150%, but also to do the share repurchases that we've made. And Scott's point was made about -- we have a reauthorization still of 7 million shares. And yes, we're going to be opportunistic. But we also feel very confident of our future generation of free cash, and that is instrumental in our decisions to move forward with the share repurchases.

headline: Cabot Oil & Gas Corporation, Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2017

componenttext: Just one last follow-up on the shareholder-friendly activities. With the high levels of expected free cash flow, if you don't deem the exploration program as a large use of capital, will the shareholder-friendly activities be all in the form of buybacks, a special dividend or yearly dividend increase? Trying to understand where the thought process is moving forward on that one.

headline: Cabot Oil & Gas Corporation, Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2017
componenttextpreview: Well, we have 2 of the 3 we've already implemented. And those 2: one, increased dividend; and two, the buybacks. Special dividends, you can look at special dividends. But what we like to see, we like to see every shareholder in our stock, and we like to s
componenttext: Well, we have 2 of the 3 we've already implemented. And those 2: one, increased dividend; and two, the buybacks. Special dividends, you can look at special dividends. But what we like to see, we like to see every shareholder in our stock, and we like to see every shareholder hold our stock for a period of time and enjoy the ride up. And by having a consistent dividend yield and increasing maybe dividend policy and also buybacks, I think would be -- the higher priority focus is then trying to suggest that we would be issuing special dividends.

headline: Cabot Oil & Gas Corporation, Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2017
componenttextpreview: Okay, I'll let Jeff take care of the compressor counterpart.

headline: Cabot Oil & Gas Corporation, Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2017
componenttextpreview: Sure, Paul. We got notified by DTE, who owns and operates the Bluestone Pipeline, which cuts through the core of Susquehanna County in our area. We were making deliveries from the station there, and they have done an inspection on a compressor station, th
componenttext: Sure, Paul. We got notified by DTE, who owns and operates the Bluestone Pipeline, which cuts through the core of Susquehanna County in our area. We were making deliveries from the station there, and they have done an inspection on a compressor station, that actually pumps gas in the Millennium Pipeline on the north end of their system. Long story short, they noticed some vibration damage to the engines and immediately shut it down, removed the engines, check out the foundation and decided that, in this particular case, the best idea going forward was simply lease 4 new engines, rebuild the station as quickly as possible and get back online. The current in-service dates we were getting now are August 23. Yes, give or take a few days. So we think we will be back in business around September 1.

componenttextpreview: I just have one question. I was curious if you could -- because Cove Point has been commissioned and looks to be taking some feed gas here. You guys, obviously, are a big supplier of that gas to Sumitomo. Are you going to be able to get physical down or t
componenttext: I just have one question. I was curious if you could -- because Cove Point has been commissioned and looks to be taking some feed gas here. You guys, obviously, are a big supplier of that gas to Sumitomo. Are you going to be able to get physical down or through some other backhaul arrangement before Sunrise comes online and capture any margin there? Or will that gas be coming from somewhere else?

headline: Cabot Oil & Gas Corporation, Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2017
componenttextpreview: Yes, I'll -- Jeff can handle that one, too.
componenttext: Yes, I'll -- Jeff can handle that one, too.

headline: Cabot Oil & Gas Corporation, Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2017
componenttextpreview: Yes, Karl. Thanks for the question. We talked about this quite a bit in preparing for a good, little while now, since we've known that Sunrise was going to be slightly delayed, on what is the best path on getting Susquehanna County gas down to the Cove Po
componenttext: Yes, Karl. Thanks for the question. We talked about this quite a bit in preparing for a good, little while now, since we've known that Sunrise was going to be slightly delayed, on what is the best path on getting Susquehanna County gas down to the Cove Point pipeline. We currently own existing capacity to get some of that gas down to the Cove Point pipeline. We're contracting with a few others that have path leading Susquehanna County to get additional volumes down the Cove Point. We have some other options with capacity holders that have valid path to feed our gathering system that run past the Cove Point pipeline. So we're working out the arrangements with them as we speak. We're looking at this from a variety of angles. For example, we're still not entirely sure when Cove Point will be up and running. We're taking on the best case that they'll be up in January, which fits us rather nicely. And i hope that we won't have any problem contracting for various path and cobble together enough transportation options to get our gas down to the pipeline.

componenttext: I think you called me earlier, Dan, and I'd stepped away. So I apologize if you did call me earlier. But just looking at the Gen 4 completions, which you've pointed out are outperforming the 4.4 Bcf per 1000 foot type curve. I recall that in going to Gen 4 from Gen 3, it was a combination of enhanced cluster spacing, some higher sand loading, some tweaks to the pumping system there. But as you look at the economics of that and the higher cost to put in a higher sand, in particular, and the tighter cluster spacing, how much of an uplift are you seeing in the actual economics, given that higher cost for what is now that higher type curve?

headline: Cabot Oil & Gas Corporation, Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2017
componenttextpreview: As far as the 4.4 increase over the Gen 3 or even looking at now our current type curve, I'm going to do a swag here and I'm probably going to get slapped back. But I think it's about 10% to 15% is the uplift, I think, we're seeing.
componenttext: As far as the 4.4 increase over the Gen 3 or even looking at now our current type curve, I'm going to do a swag here and I'm probably going to get slapped back. But I think it's about 10% to 15% is the uplift, I think, we're seeing.

headline: Cabot Oil & Gas Corporation, Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2017
componenttextpreview: And then, I guess, similarly in the Eagle Ford, I know you didn't put out the type curves because it's taken longer for the longer laterals to clean up. There, you'd gone from 1,600 pounds per foot to 2,000 pounds per foot. Similarly, is that providing en
componenttext: And then, I guess, similarly in the Eagle Ford, I know you didn't put out the type curves because it's taken longer for the longer laterals to clean up. There, you'd gone from 1,600 pounds per foot to 2,000 pounds per foot. Similarly, is that providing enhanced economics, and you then go to even higher sand loading? Or what are you seeing as far as optimizing the sand loading in the Eagle Ford?

headline: Cabot Oil & Gas Corporation, Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2017
componenttextpreview: Well, we have a little bit of discussion, Bob, on additional loading, cluster spacing. Steve went over. And looking at our flow-back periods with the longer laterals, more water pump to carry the excess -- extra load and more clusters, we're looking at th
componenttext: Well, we have a little bit of discussion, Bob, on additional loading, cluster spacing. Steve went over. And looking at our flow-back periods with the longer laterals, more water pump to carry the excess -- extra load and more clusters, we're looking at the tweaks. And as Steve mentioned, if you have more water around near wellbore, more loading, you push back some of the volumes back until they work their way back to the wellbore. Initially, it certainly, with the rate it comes back, does affect the rate of return. And so we're at early, early stage of trying to evaluate just exactly what is going to be the best recipe to get the most return out of those project without compromising EUR and cost. So it's still early, and it's work in progress. And all the data gathering and database that we're building, trying to build our big data platform as others are, we are going to be looking at it and utilizing the data to make decisions in the future.

headline: Cabot Oil & Gas Corporation, Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2017
componenttextpreview: An then just lastly, real quick, back to the Gen 5 completions. Is that strictly just reducing cost? Or does Gen 5 in the Marcellus also entail some greater sand loading or even tighter cluster spacing?
componenttext: An then just lastly, real quick, back to the Gen 5 completions. Is that strictly just reducing cost? Or does Gen 5 in the Marcellus also entail some greater sand loading or even tighter cluster spacing?

headline: Cabot Oil & Gas Corporation, Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2017
componenttextpreview: Well, it's just different. And yes, we are trying to do a little bit of both. We're trying to see what cost can be taken out by different a completion there. We're trying to make a determination, does it also affect initial rates and EURs on the completio
componenttext: Well, it's just different. And yes, we are trying to do a little bit of both. We're trying to see what cost can be taken out by different a completion there. We're trying to make a determination, does it also affect initial rates and EURs on the completions. Too early time to speculate where we are with that.

headline: Cabot Oil & Gas Corporation, Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2017
componenttextpreview: And today's final question comes from Marshall Carver of Heikkinen Energy Advisors.
componenttext: And today's final question comes from Marshall Carver of Heikkinen Energy Advisors.

headline: Cabot Oil & Gas Corporation, Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2017
componenttextpreview: Yes, just trying to connect the dots here. Your comments that you're looking for core rates of return with your exploration programs similar to the Marcellus, that just seems like an almost an impossibly high hurdle. If it doesn't compete, would you expec
componenttext: Yes, just trying to connect the dots here. Your comments that you're looking for core rates of return with your exploration programs similar to the Marcellus, that just seems like an almost an impossibly high hurdle. If it doesn't compete, would you expect to sell it and, therefore, you probably would sell it because it's hard to find anything that could possibly compete? Or am I thinking about that wrong? It just seems like 100% rates of return are -- it's a really, really tough bar to clear.

headline: Cabot Oil & Gas Corporation, Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2017
componenttextpreview: Yes. Marshall, I don't put the core definition as only what our return is in the Marcellus. There are some areas out there that I think have core -- what I would define as core returns that might not be the returns of the Marcellus. But their returns, if
componenttext:
Yes. Marshall, I don't put the core definition as only what our return is in the Marcellus. There are some areas out there that I think have core -- what I would define as core returns that might not be the returns of the Marcellus. But their returns, if that was where you are strictly focused, would allow for -- even though less returns than the Marcellus, would still allow for growth and return of free cash. And that is somewhere in between, which I have not defined, between our Eagle Ford and our Marcellus. 
So there is a swap in between there. Obviously, on the upper end, that says, yes, these would be core projects. And you're right in your assessment. How you define a core and looking at the number of companies that are able to spend the money, drill the wells, complete them, put them in the pipeline, grow double digits and generate free cash and give free cash back to shareholders, there's not many that fall in that definition.  But that definition is, I think, somewhat below what our Marcellus return is, but it is a very, very high bar to get to. 
And that's what we're trying to do. We recognize that if you go -- just like the comments we've made on the Eagle Ford, some would say that, "Why are you spending money in the Eagle Ford? Go spend it all in the Marcellus, because you're diluting your return profile." We get the math. The difference is that, that has not deterred from anything we've done in the Marcellus. We've been handicapped without infrastructure up there. We think we're getting close to that. We don't think anything we're doing in these 2 projects to try to determine, can we find a really, really good -- another return project to get -- some of our capital allocation. It will not impact $1 that we plan to allocate to our Marcellus and our anticipation of filling, all incrementally, the infrastructure volumes that we're going to grow, too, in the Marcellus. But what we are -- and to the point that maybe another question referred to, how do we balance giving back to shareholders as opposed to investing into a -- or a gas well. 
Well, we've decided to give some back to shareholders right now because we don't have a place that is going to allow us to meet our benchmark of growing and generating free cash after you do the full-cycle return profile of our projects. And if we get to the point that we would hope to get -- and I might add that in our initial economics that we run to make the first decisions to spend capital, to look for those type of ideas, we certainly have economics and a development plan in scope, though speculative, that would do what I'm talking about. And that is invest, develop, have a development program, get to the point of growth where free cash -- the program is supporting on its own cash generation and also generating free cash for other optionality and as we have suggested and as we have done, and that is to get back to shareholders.

headline: Cabot Oil & Gas Corporation, Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2017
componenttextpreview: Good morning, and welcome to the Cabot Oil & Gas Corporation Third Quarter 2017 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] Please note, this event is being recorded.I would now like to turn the conference over to Dan Dinges, Chairman, President a
componenttext:
Good morning, and welcome to the Cabot Oil & Gas Corporation Third Quarter 2017 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] Please note, this event is being recorded.
I would now like to turn the conference over to Dan Dinges, Chairman, President and CEO. Please go ahead.

headline: Cabot Oil & Gas Corporation, Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2017
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Drew, and good morning to all. Thank you for joining us today for Cabot's third quarter 2017 earnings call. With me today are the members of the Cabot's executive team. They are usually here. Before we get started, I'd like to highlight that on
componenttext:
Thank you, Drew, and good morning to all. Thank you for joining us today for Cabot's third quarter 2017 earnings call. With me today are the members of the Cabot's executive team. They are usually here. Before we get started, I'd like to highlight that on this call, we will make forward-looking statements based on current expectations. Also, some of our comments may refer to non-GAAP financial measures. Forward-looking statements and other disclaimers as well as reconciliations to the most directly comparable GAAP financial measures are provided in this morning's earnings release. 
For the third quarter, Cabot demonstrated its continued focus on disciplined capital allocation by generating positive free cash flow for the sixth consecutive quarter, while delivering 12% equivalent production growth. Operating cash flow increased by 79% year-over-year, driven by the production growth, coupled with a 60% increase in cash margins. On natural gas, price realizations increased 16% year-over-year. It should come as no surprise that the third quarter realizations were weaker sequentially due to lower NYMEX price and wider differentials. The widening of differentials in the third quarter has been seen in Appalachia over the last few years and highlights the need for the long anticipated in service of new long-haul infrastructure and in-basin demand projects. Our expectation is that our price realizations will only improve moving forward given the in-service of numerous infrastructure projects over the next few quarters. 
Year-to-date, we have generated approximately $125 million of free cash flow and received over $30 million of proceeds from noncore assets sales, which have allowed us to return almost $125 million of capital to shareholders year-to-date via dividends and share repurchases, and to reduce our net debt position, further improving our strong balance sheet. 
As it relates to share repurchase, while we did not buyback shares during the third quarter, I would highlight that we remain optimistic on this front and take advantage of disconnects in the market, like the recent 9% selloff we experienced during our recent trading blackout period, which did begin after the end of the third quarter. 
In this morning's release, we reaffirmed our capital guidance and tightened our production guidance range for the year, while leaving the midpoint unchanged, where we ended up in the production [indiscernible] where we end up in the production guidance range. We will ultimately be dependent on in-basin pricing during the fourth quarter as Cabot has recently been electing curtail a small portion of its production when pricing is value destruction. 
As we have reiterated many times before, while production is a byproduct of our capital allocation through high retain projects, we are not a chasing top line production growth for the sake of it and have absolutely no problem holding back volumes if the prices do not warrant moving additional gas at certain times. However, I'm not overly concerned about the recent price dynamics given that over the last few years, we have seen some of the widest differentials during the month of October, which has subsequently been followed by a significant improvement in basis. 
As most of you are aware, Atlantic Sunrise received its final notice to proceed during the quarter, with pipeline and compression station construction beginning in September. This is a milestone we've been waiting for since our first announcement and our involvement in the project back in February 2014, and represents a key inflection point for the Northeast Pennsylvania natural gas market and for Cabot. We continue to target a mid-2018 in-service to this project on which will be selling approximately 1 Bcf of new -- of gas to new markets. Tennessee Gas Pipeline recently reaffirmed that its Orion Project is ahead of schedule and it's anticipated to be in service as early as December '17. Additionally, the 2 power plant projects that we are sole suppliers to, Moxie Freedom and Lackawanna Energy Center, are currently under construction and on schedule for their early September -- or excuse me, summer 2018 in service. 
As it relates to Constitution Pipeline, the parties of these project recently submitted a petition for a declaratory order with the FERC, demonstrating that the New York DEC exceeded its statutory time frame to grant or deny the Section 401 certification for the project. The Clean Water Act specifies that if a state agency fails or refuses to act on a request for certification under Section 401 within a reasonable period of time, the certification requirement shall be waived. It is our belief that New York DEC clearly failed that on Constitution's application for a Section 401 water quality certification within a reasonable period of time. If the FERC grants Constitution's petition, Constitution will promptly seek a Clean Water Act Section 404 permit from the U.S. Army Corps of Engineers. We continue to believe this is a project that New York needs to achieve its energy goal, which will require a mix of resources, including natural gas, in order to keep breaks low and supply reliable for Power Generation for the state. 
In line with state energy goals, Constitution will lower emissions by enabling customers switch from heating oil to cleaner burning natural gas. In line with our conservative forecast, we currently exclude the benefits of our capacity on Constitution from our 5-year plan. However, I certainly would not count this project out. 
In this morning's release, we initiated our official 2018 daily production growth guidance, with a range of 15% to 20%, which implies a 17% to 22% pro forma for West Virginia divesture. This production growth is based on capital budget range of $1.025 billion to 1.150 billion, consisting of $750 million to $850 million in the Marcellus, $125 million to $150 million in the Eagle Ford, $75 million in our exploration play and $75 million  for pipeline investments in Atlantic Sunrise and other corporate capital expenditures. We plan to operate 3 rigs and realized  2 completion crews in the Marcellus Shale during 2018. Our pace of completion activity will ultimately dictate where we land within the Marcellus capital range and will be dependent upon market conditions during the year. While we could certainly grow faster than our current guidance, our focus is on maximizing margins, returns and free cash flow, and we firmly believe the flexibility in this current plan allows us to make the most prudent capital allocation decisions throughout the year in response to market dynamics. Capital range for the Marcellus in 2018 will position Cabot from Marcellus production growth of 27% to 33% in 2019. Based on current market indications for natural gas prices, we expect our natural gas price realizations to average $0.45 to $0.50 below NYMEX for the full year of 2018, a significant improvement over 2017 levels. In the Eagle Ford, we plan to operate 1 rig for the full year and utilize 1 completion crew for a portion of the year. The plan allows for us to maintain all or acreage, provide for single-digit growth in oil production and generate positive free cash flow at the current strip. Our capital range for the Eagle Ford will depend on our outlook for all price, with a focus on generating cash flow from this assets as opposed to growth for the sake of growth. We plan to spend $75 million during the first half of '18, continuing to test our 2 new exploratory areas to better understand if they have the attribute we are looking for in order to compete for our capital internally. We would like to be in a position by mid-'18 or sooner to make a decision on whether we move forward with continued activity on these areas based on our results from the first half of the year. As we have stated before, if we do ultimately have a success in these years, we will look to divest assets, to find any near-term deficit spends in these areas that would need to recur before the assets become self funding and free cash flow positive, similar to what we did in the Marcellus years ago. And for example, on the cash flow raise, while fairly small in nature, we are currently marketing our remaining Haynesville properties as we continue to high-grade our portfolio. Based on current strip prices, our 2018 program would deliver the following highlights: Double-digit corporate rate of returns, positive free cash flow of over $200 million at midpoint of the capital budget range, a deleveraging of the balance sheet to below 1x debt to EBITDA, production growth of 15% to 20% and positions the company for significant growth in free cash flow and production in 2019 and '20 as we highlighted in the 3-year Marcellus outlook we included in this morning's release. 
Further on our 3-year outlook, the Marcellus is expected to deliver a 3-year Marcellus production CAGR of 20%-plus and a 3-year Marcellus discretionary cash flow CAGR of 25%-plus percent, assuming current strip prices. Based on this plan, Cabot's Marcellus asset will generate approximately $2.5 billion of cumulative pretax, free cash flow from 2018 to 2020, while averaging between $750 million to $850 million of annual Marcellus capital expenditures over this period. This program only assumes we have the benefit of the infrastructure that is currently under construction, including Atlantic Sunrise and the other 2 power plant projects that we have mentioned. Obviously, any incremental capacity on long-term sales could provide additional upside. Given this level of free cash flow generation, we expect our debt adjusted per share growth metric to look even better than our absolute growth numbers. I would also highlight that based on our internal estimates, as well as consensus estimates for 2019, this plan will generate a best-in-class free cash flow yield compared to the rest of the E&P companies in the S&P 500. While it's premature at this point to outline a specific plan for allocation of free cash flow, we fully expect to return an increasing amount of capital to shareholders we a dividend growth and share repurchases as well as evaluating the potential reduction of debt as near-term maturities come to. 
Our longer-term capital allocation to assets outside of the Marcellus will ultimately be dependent on our outlook for oil prices and the outcome of our ongoing exploration testing. However, as I mentioned earlier, we are focused on delivering a self-funded program in Eagle Ford and funding any initial deficit spends in our exploration areas with asset sales. 
In summary, we have a 3-year plan that provides double-digit, returns focused per share growth, while generating significant free cash flow at the current strip, and delivers double-digit corporate wide returns that stand out, not only among energy companies, but also across the broad market, which certainly makes Cabot an attractive investment, regardless of anybody's view on the energy space. Drew, with that, I'll be happy to answer any questions.

componenttext: Well, we have an economic price that covers our cost to capital close to $1. But we have seen, in some of the gas we move in the daily market, which is a not a large percentage of our gas, but we move gas in the daily market, and that some of the gas that we remove and we saw gas that was below $1 on the realizations over several weekends and periods of time that were low demand periods. And that is the gas volumes that we would like to not move.

headline: Cabot Oil & Gas Corporation, Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2017
componenttextpreview: Okay, that's a good. And my second question, it's [indiscernible] $2.5  million is a lot of free cash flow you've got options between you can buy it back up to 20% for stock you could pay a meaningful S&P type dividend on the shares. How do you think abou
componenttext: Okay, that's a good. And my second question, it's [indiscernible] $2.5  million is a lot of free cash flow you've got options between you can buy it back up to 20% for stock you could pay a meaningful S&P type dividend on the shares. How do you think about those 2 options in reallocating or returning that capital shareholders? And obviously the share buybacks depend on the stock price. But close to current levels, how to think about the options between share buyback sent dividend increase?

headline: Cabot Oil & Gas Corporation, Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2017
componenttextpreview: Well, we recently, as you are aware, increased our dividend 150%. We also bought back a nice tranche of shares in the second quarter. We do have an authorization still on the shelf to buy back shares. When you compare those 2, we will, I think, look at bo
componenttext: Well, we recently, as you are aware, increased our dividend 150%. We also bought back a nice tranche of shares in the second quarter. We do have an authorization still on the shelf to buy back shares. When you compare those 2, we will, I think, look at both of them as an avenue to get back money to shareholders. On the dividend, we are moving towards a much more certainty catch to our free cash flow generation now that we have the approval of the infrastructure in the ground. With that infrastructure underground and gas moving through additional outlets and also seeing the basis compressed in the 3 pipes that we currently sell into, we're going to have a significant level of confidence than ongoing continuous improvement in the realizations. And with that, that gives us a little bit more confidence on just the dividend side of our give back. In the meantime, however though, we have had, as you're aware, $0.5 billion or so of cash on our balance sheet and we have continued to rationalize our portfolio and we look at the buybacks with some of that cash. So to say it a little bit more specifically, once we get the infrastructure in place, we know we're going to be generating a significant level of free cash. And with that, we'll then make decisions between these share buybacks and the dividends and look at that as prudently as we can.

headline: Cabot Oil & Gas Corporation, Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2017
componenttextpreview: Well, and I'd like to hear your comment also, Michael. We look at that as a unique position for an E&P company. The cash flow yield of not only that but we think we can increase that free cash flow yield the. If you compare that free cash flow yield to ot
componenttext: Well, and I'd like to hear your comment also, Michael. We look at that as a unique position for an E&P company. The cash flow yield of not only that but we think we can increase that free cash flow yield the. If you compare that free cash flow yield to other industries out there and you look at our multiples, I would like to see what The Street thinks the value is of an E&P company that does deliver that type of yield. And if we can get of the reaction from The Street and the value that free cash flow yield in a way that we think merits the valuation per share of Cabot's stock, then buying back shares is not going to be as big of interest to us because we're going to see it in stock price appreciation. But to date, even though we think that is very visible on that yield improving as we go forward, I haven't seen the comparison of The Street giving us the credit in our current share price.

headline: Cabot Oil & Gas Corporation, Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2017
componenttextpreview: Yes. I just make a comment and then I'll turn it over to Scott and let him make a comment also. But on the capacity side, we are entirely comfortable with the production growth that we have indicated. It is our plan as we discussed in the past, David, to
componenttext: Yes. I just make a comment and then I'll turn it over to Scott and let him make a comment also. But on the capacity side, we are entirely comfortable with the production growth that we have indicated. It is our plan as we discussed in the past, David, to certainly fill the new infrastructure with some of the existing gas that we're producing today. And also have incremental volumes that go into filling the Atlantic Sunrise in those 2 power plants. We do expect the uplift that you've referenced in the differential on the existing pipes. However, if in fact the area rationalization by other operators out there would move into the space and try to back fill where Cabot has moved gas off of those 3 pipes and onto new markets if there's backfilling and rationalization by the -- or the lack of rationalization by other operators out there, then Cabot is not going to give up a great deal of its market share. We will be there and us being the lowest cost producer out there, we will certainly protect our market share. Of 10, to for it to Scott also.

headline: Cabot Oil & Gas Corporation, Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2017
componenttextpreview: Well, we've always look at the Eagle Ford as a good alternative to allocating some of our capital, and we continue to improve our efficiencies and our completion results out there on the field. When you look at the impact of the Eagle Ford on Cabot as far
componenttext: Well, we've always look at the Eagle Ford as a good alternative to allocating some of our capital, and we continue to improve our efficiencies and our completion results out there on the field. When you look at the impact of the Eagle Ford on Cabot as far as it being a use of proceeds, we don't look at that as a large use of proceeds with our plan of allocating capital to the Marcellus, also with our plan of giving money back to the shareholder, and we do anticipate that with success in our 2 exploratory areas, that the Eagle Ford that fit into our capital allocation today, but if it does not rank within our hierarchy of where would like to allocate capital in the future, then the Eagle Ford, as we have said, ended by the past, as an asset that we would look at to help fund our new ventures.

headline: Cabot Oil & Gas Corporation, Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2017
componenttextpreview: Yes. Shawls, there's a lot similar to speaking this summer or endless summer in terms of mild summers and low demand. Storage being a pretty much the same levels and a lot of gas in the market. I think one unique characteristic this year is probably more

componenttext: Yes. Good questions. I'll ask comment. We've been asked that probably. So we are going to continue to be able to try to improve our completions and in that regard, we in fact, have a couple of beta tests going on right now for our Gen 6 completions. So standby on the results of that. When you look at the difference between Gen 4 and Gen 5, one of the changes we made is the Gen 4's got power on the stage spacing. In Gen 5, we went wider by quarter again of the stage spacing, but we had an improved or increased the clusters in the Gen 5 from the 4. Additionally, the fluid pumped in the Gen 4 is a little bit less than the fluid pumped in the Gen 5 to move the volumes that we are moving in the Gen 5. We are staying consistent with the amount of profit per foot. But by widening the business between stages, we are reducing the numbers stages that the will have to pump and a drill out time that will have on getting the well ready for completion. So that's some of the tweaks without the details, that's some of the tweaks that we have between Gen 4 and Gen 5.

So appreciate the interest, and we look forward to our call after the end of the year. Thank you very much.
